awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Analyses, Measurements and Modeling in Support of the Asian Monsoon Chemical and Climate Impact Project (ACCLIP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This effort involves an aircraft study of the chemistry and dynamics of the Asian Summer Monsoon (ASM).  This atmospheric circulation takes place in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere and spans the Pacific Ocean east of Asia westward to the Middle East.  The vertical transport of pollutants within the ASM can have a global impact on atmospheric chemistry and radiation.  This project includes the training of graduate students and post-doctoral scientists.

The four main objectives of the project are: (1) Investigate the transport pathway of the ASM uplifted air from inside of the anticyclone to the global upper troposphere-lower stratosphere (UTLS); (2) Sample the chemical content of air processed in the ASM to ascertain its role in UTLS ozone chemistry, and in re-distributing active species and short-lived climate forcers to examine the respective roles of Asian pollution and the monsoon strength in chemistry and climate, and to understand two-way coupling between chemistry and climate.  Chemical tracers of different lifetimes can also help characterize the ASM uplifting time scales, which are difficult for the models to estimate; (3) Obtain information on aerosol size, mass and chemical composition necessary for determining the radiative impact of the ASM, for constraining models of aerosol formation and for contrasting the organic-rich ASM UTLS aerosol population with that of sulfate-rich volcanic plumes and the background aerosol population; and (4) Measure the water vapor distribution associated with the monsoon dynamical structure to evaluate transport across the tropopause, and determine the role of the ASM in water vapor transport into the stratosphere.

This project is scheduled to take place during July-August 2020 and will establish and expand collaborations between several academic institutions, government partners, and international institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The primary goal of this collaborative proposal was to investigate the impact of the Asian Summer Monsoon on the chemical composition of the upper troposphere. The impact of the monsoon was assessed by the joint NSF/NASA airborne field campaign ACCLIP (Asian summer monsoon Chemical and Climate Impact Project).  Our focus was to deploy a chemical ionization mass spectrometer (CIMS) to measure sulfur dioxide from the NCAR GV research aircraft during ACCLP. Measurements of sulfur dioxide were obtained along with observations of nitric acid, pernitric acid, and hydrochloric acid. These species were all submitted to the archive of the final mission data.

Intellectual Merit

Observations form the campaign demonstrated that emissions from East Asia had a much larger impact on the composition of the upper troposphere than those from South Asia. Our data demonstrated that the largest levels of upper tropospheric sulfur dioxide originated from East Asia. In addition, a large fraction of the sulfur dioxide observed at high altitude could be accounted for by anthropogenic emissions of carbonyl disulfide.

Broader Impacts

The ACCLIP project provided training for two graduate and one undergraduate student from Georgia Tech. Both of the graduate students completed their degrees and the undergraduate student is now pursuing a Ph.D. at Colorado State University. In addition, a new high intensity, vacuum ultraviolet ion source was developed for the CIMS that does not require radioactive material. This ion source has been adopted by a large number of research groups and is now commercially available.
